document_title: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction: Causes and symptoms
subsection_content:
Certain risk factors can increase your chance of having a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction, and these may or may not be under your control.
Controllable factors
Tobacco use and smoking; Diet, including intake of salt (blood pressure), sugar (diabetes) or fat (cholesterol); Level of physical activity; Drug use (especially stimulants such as amphetamine, cocaine, or any other drugs that affect the heart)
Uncontrollable factors
Age: The older you are, the higher the risk, the greater the risk of having a heart attack; Gender: Men tend to have heart attacks earlier than women. The risk for men begins to increase at age 45, while for women, the risk begins to increase at age 50 (or after menopause, whichever occurs first); Family history: The risk increases earlier if the patient has a father or brother diagnosed with heart disease or a heart attack before age 55, or a mother or sister similarly diagnosed before age 65.; Genetics or conditions present at birth: Some disorders in the body can affect other systems in the body, thereby increasing the risk of heart attack. This includes genetic (inherited) or congenital conditions.
